name: Total charitable giving
description: Perhaps the most frequently invoked statistic related to giving is aggregate charitable giving, which combines donations to 501(c)(3) organizations from individuals (living donors and bequests) and institutions (corporations and foundations).

measures.name: Total charitable contributions
measures.notes: Estimates rely on econometric methods developed by the Indiana University Lilly Family School of Philanthropy and tabulation of tax data, economic indicators, and demographics.

name: Individual giving
description: Individuals, as opposed to institutions, have long represented the largest source of charitable giving in the United States. Giving by the very wealthy continues to represent a disproportionately large share of giving by individuals.

measures.name: Share of total charitable contributions made by individuals
measures.notes: Estimates rely on econometric methods developed by the Indiana University Lilly Family School of Philanthropy and tabulation of tax data, economic indicators, and demographics.

measures.name: Total charitable contributions made by individuals
measures.notes: Estimates rely on econometric methods developed by the Indiana University Lilly Family School of Philanthropy and tabulation of tax data, economic indicators, and demographics.

measures.name: Total donations made by ultra-wealthy individuals in the United States
measures.notes: Estimates are calculated by Wealth-X’s Philanthropic Giving Model, which analyzes the annual philanthropic donations made by the ultra-wealthy defined as those with a net worth of more than $30 million) in each market. Wealth-X then uses its proprietary Wealth and Investable Assets Model to estimate total philanthropic giving (as a proportion of total wealth) in each region. These figures exclude giving by corporations as well as businesses owned by the ultra-high-net-worth.

measures.name: Share of charitable donations less than $5,001
measures.notes: Estimates are based on GivingTuesday’s Growth in Giving dataset, a longitudinal dataset of donation transactions by individuals in the United States aggregated from many sources (including customer relationship management databases and other giving platforms). Transactions included in this dataset are limited to those made to 501(c)(3)s with no more than $25 million in contributions and with data from three consecutive years.

name: Noncash charitable contributions
description: Not all giving comes in the form of cash. Many organizations accept noncash assets, including publicly traded securities (stocks, bonds, and mutual funds) and non–publicly traded assets (private stock, restricted stock, and limited partnership interests). These contributions can be itemized on taxpayers’ yearly tax returns.

measures.name: Share of noncash assets among all itemized charitable contributions

sources.source: IRS SOI Tax Stats: Individual Income Tax Returns Complete Report

measures.notes: The IRS Statistics of Income Division calculates noncash (or “other than cash”) charitable contributions by aggregating data from itemized individual tax returns.

measures.name: Total annual value of noncash charitable contributions

sources.source: IRS SOI Tax Stats: Individual Income Tax Returns Complete Report

measures.notes: The IRS Statistics of Income Division calculates noncash (or “other than cash”) charitable contributions by aggregating data from itemized individual tax returns. In our November 29, 2022 update, we corrected the unit value from “millions of dollars ($)” to “billions of dollars ($).”

name: Volunteering
description: Volunteering is a core way individuals express generosity. Much of the data on volunteering registers how individuals help tax-exempt nonprofit institutions, but volunteers can also assist informal organizations and associations.

measures.name: Share of Americans who volunteer

sources.source: Current Population Survey: Volunteering and Civic Life Supplement

measures.notes: Estimates are pulled from the Current Population Survey Volunteering and Civic Life Supplement. This supplement was administered by the Bureau of Labor Statistics from 2002 to 2015 and since 2017 has been administered by the Corporation for National and Community Service. Only data prior to the change are presented here. The count of volunteers only includes people who volunteered through or for an organization. The figures do not include people who volunteered in a more informal manner.

measures.name: Total hours volunteered

sources.source: Current Population Survey: Volunteering and Civic Life Supplement

measures.notes: Estimates are pulled from the Current Population Survey Volunteering and Civic Life Supplement. This supplement was administered by the Bureau of Labor Statistics from 2002 to 2015 and since 2017 has been administered by the Corporation for National and Community Service. Only data prior to the change are presented here. The count of volunteers only includes people who volunteered through or for an organization. The figures do not include people who volunteered in a more informal manner. In our November 29, 2022 update, we corrected two transposed numbers in the 2015 data point, changing 8.42987B to 8.49287B.

measures.name: Share of Americans who volunteered in the past year
measures.notes: Estimates rely on telephone interviews conducted by pollsters with a random sample of more than 1,000 adults living in all 50 states and the District of Columbia. Respondents were asked separately about donating money and volunteering time to charitable organizations.

measures.name: Number of blood donors in the United States

sources.source: US Department of Health and Human Services Office of Infectious Disease and HIV/AIDS Policy

measures.notes: Estimates are drawn from the National Blood Collection and Utilization Survey, which is fielded to all US blood collection centers and acute care hospitals (with the exception of Department of Defense facilities) performing at least 100 inpatient surgical procedures per year and located within the 50 states and the District of Columbia.

name: Impact investing
description: Individuals and institutions make impact investments to intentionally seek social and environmental impact alongside financial returns. Impact investing represents one way in which the notion of giving has expanded beyond donations to charitable organizations.

measures.name: Share of high-net-worth households that participate in impact investing

sources.source: Bank of America/Indiana University Lilly Family School of Philanthropy

measures.notes: Estimates are from 2021, are based on a nationally representative random sample of 1,626 high-net-worth households, and include in-depth analysis based on age, gender, race, and sexual identity by Indiana University’s Lilly Family School of Philanthropy. High-net-worth households are defined as those with a net worth of at least $1 million and/or with an annual income of at least $200,000.

measures.name: Total donor-advised fund assets in impact investment pools at Fidelity Charitable
measures.notes: Estimates are calculated using data from 174,592 giving accounts in Fidelity Charitable’s internal reporting database.

measures.name: Total amount of recoverable grants made by Fidelity Charitable donor-advised funds to charities
measures.notes: Recoverable grants are donations that can be repaid under some circumstances. Estimates are calculated using data from 174,592 giving accounts in Fidelity Charitable’s internal reporting database.

name: Political giving
description: Traditionally, giving to political campaigns has not been considered a form of charitable giving. But the lines between political and charitable giving are becoming increasingly blurred through giving vehicles such as limited liability companies. Donations to party-focused organizations such as WinRed or ActBlue as well as donations to individual candidates and campaigns constitute political giving. (Gifts to 501(c)(4)s and political action committees are not included in this summary.)

measures.name: Total donors that gave over $200 to a political campaign
measures.notes: Estimates are taken from the Federal Election Commission, aggregated every calendar year (January—December). Fluctuations in political donations year to year are partially attributable to election cycles (e.g., presidential election years versus off-year elections).

measures.name: Total money contributed to political campaigns via donations over $200
measures.notes: Estimates are taken from the Federal Election Commission, aggregated every calendar year (January—December). Fluctuations in political donations year to year are partially attributable to election cycles (e.g., presidential election years versus off-year elections).

measures.name: Money donated to WinRed
measures.notes: An online donation platform launched in June 2019, WinRed enables individuals to donate to Republican candidates and campaigns nationwide. Estimates include aggregate annual donations made to political campaigns using WinRed’s platform.

measures.name: Money donated to ActBlue
measures.notes: An online donation platform launched in 2004, ActBlue enables individuals to donate to Democratic candidates and campaigns nationwide. Estimates include aggregate annual donations made to political campaigns using ActBlue’s platform. In our November 29, 2022 update, we corrected two data points that were rounded incorrectly. For 2019, we changed $1.05 billion to $1.06 billion, and for 2020, we changed $4.02 billion to $4.03 billion.

name: Giving by bequest
description: Charitable bequests, which are tax-deductible gifts given through wills or trusts, can come in many forms and represent a significant share of total charitable contributions.

measures.name: Total giving by bequest
measures.notes: Estimates rely on econometric methods developed by the Indiana University Lilly Family School of Philanthropy and tabulation of tax data, economic indicators, and demographics. In our November 29, 2022 update, we corrected the 2018 data point, which had been rounded incorrectly. We changed $39.72 billion to $39.71 billion.

measures.name: Share of total charitable contributions given through bequests
measures.notes: Estimates rely on econometric methods developed by the Indiana University Lilly Family School of Philanthropy and tabulation of tax data, economic indicators, and demographics.

name: Remittance giving
description: Remittance giving involves (often recurring) person-to-person payments of relatively small sums by migrants in one country to people in their home countries.

measures.name: Remittances sent from US residents abroad
measures.notes: Estimates are based on the International Monetary Fund’s balance of payments data.

name: Donor-advised funds
description: Donor-advised funds (DAFs) are giving accounts established at public charities that allow donors to make a charitable contribution, receive an immediate tax deduction, and recommend grants over time. The public charities maintain legal control over the contributions and work with the donor, who can advise on funding recommendations.

measures.name: Total value of contributions made to DAFs
measures.notes: Estimates are drawn from a longitudinal study of a representative sample from 995 charitable sponsors that reported DAF assets in any year.

measures.name: Total number of DAFs in the United States
measures.notes: Estimates are drawn from a longitudinal study of a representative sample from 995 charitable sponsors that reported DAF assets in any year.

measures.name: Share of DAF contributions made as noncash assets at Fidelity Charitable
measures.notes: Estimates are calculated using data from an estimated 174,592 giving accounts in Fidelity Charitable’s internal reporting database. Noncash assets include publicly traded securities (stocks, bonds, and mutual funds) and non–publicly traded assets (private stock, restricted stock, and limited partnership interests).

measures.name: Total dollars distributed to nonprofits from DAFs at community foundations
measures.notes: Estimates are sourced from a nonrepresentative survey of 84 US community foundations. The study was conducted between late 2020 and early 2021.

name: Workplace giving
description: Americans have long donated to charity through their employers, often via contributions channeled through payroll deductions. Employers would traditionally either donate these earmarked contributions directly to intermediary charities or through campaigns like the Combined Federal Campaign. But workplace giving has shifted in recent decades as new technology and norms have given individual employees more autonomy over their charitable gifts.

measures.name: Total value of donations made through Benevity
measures.notes: Benevity provides software that facilitates workplace giving and is used by many Fortune 500 companies. Estimates use Benevity’s master database, which includes activities of more than 650 companies, including clients, users of the software, and the community of causes.

measures.name: Aggregate charitable contributions from workplace giving programs
measures.notes: Estimates are drawn from a 2017 survey conducted by America’s Charities of 1,586 employees representing 18 industry groups (including education, finance, government, health care, technology, nonprofits, professional services, and consumer products). This is the most comprehensive and recent data point capturing the scale of workplace giving.

measures.name: Total dollars pledged by federal employees through the Combined Federal Campaign
measures.notes: The Combined Federal Campaign is a federal workplace-giving campaign that enables federal employees and retirees to pledge monetary support to approved charities. Summary figures are released by the Office of Personnel Management and include aggregated pledges to charities by federal employees participating in the campaign.

measures.name: Participation rate of federal employees in the Combined Federal Campaign
measures.notes: The Combined Federal Campaign is a federal workplace-giving campaign that enables federal employees and retirees to pledge monetary support to approved charities. Summary figures are released by the Office of Personnel Management and include aggregated pledges to charities by federal employees participating in the campaign.

name: Online giving
description: Online giving includes any gift made through the internet, on any device or platform. As more organizations have started accepting donations made using a credit or debit card, online giving has increased.

measures.name: Share of all donations, excluding grants, made online
measures.notes: Estimates are drawn from financial analysis of Blackbaud clients. The latest study was conducted from January to December 2021 and included 4,535 nonprofit organizations. The analysis does not include the unfulfilled proportions of pledged gifts or recurring gifts processed offline.

measures.name: Percentage change in number of online donations
measures.notes: These estimates use anonymized and aggregated Mastercard transaction data to provide an analysis of current and historical donation trends.

measures.name: Percentage change in individual donations made through electronic payments
measures.notes: These estimates use anonymized and aggregated Mastercard transaction data to provide an analysis of current and historical donation trends.

name: Point of sale
description: Charity checkout campaigns offer customers an opportunity to donate during the checkout or payment process by rounding up, adding to their total, or having the vendor automatically make a contribution on their behalf.

measures.name: Money raised by major charity checkout campaigns
measures.notes: Estimates are aggregated self-reported data from 76 fundraising campaigns that have raised at least $1,000,000.

measures.name: Total donations to charities via Lyft’s Round Up and Donate program
measures.notes: Started in 2017, the rideshare company Lyft’s Round Up and Donate program enables passengers to donate to one of 20 pre-selected charities. These estimates provided by Lyft show how much their riders have donated to Lyft’s sponsored charitable organizations since the program began.

measures.name: Total donated to charities from AmazonSmile
measures.notes: Estimates are drawn from aggregated donations made via AmazonSmile, a program where shoppers can buy products through smile.amazon.com and choose from over 1 million eligible 501(c)(3) public charitable organizations to which Amazon will donate 0.5 percent of eligible purchases.

name: Digital currency
description: As digital currencies like Bitcoin become more popular, more charitable organizations are allowing digital currency donations. In recent years, some donors have made extremely large contributions involving cryptocurrency, though the exact values of the donations have fluctuated dramatically given the high volatility of many cryptocurrencies.

measures.name: Charitable contributions in the form of cryptocurrency to Fidelity Charitable
measures.notes: Estimates are calculated using data from 174,592 giving accounts in Fidelity Charitable’s internal reporting database.

measures.name: Cryptocurrency charitable contributions to the Giving Block
measures.notes: An online platform launched in 2018, the Giving Block enables nonprofits to accept donations of cryptocurrency and donors to find these nonprofits. Estimates include aggregate annual cryptocurrency donations made using the Giving Block’s platform.

name: Donor participation
description: One of the distinguishing characteristics of charitable giving in the United States has long been the large share of Americans who report giving to charitable organizations. But some research suggests that in recent years, this share has steadily declined. Whether this decline in the “donor pool” reflects a lessening or a rechanneling of charitable giving is a major question confronting researchers.

measures.name: Share of US households that reported donating money to one or more charitable organizations the previous year

sources.source: Indiana University Lilly Family School of Philanthropy

measures.notes: These data are from the Indiana University Lilly Family School of Philanthropy’s Philanthropy Panel Study (PPS), which is a module of the University of Michigan’s Panel Study of Income Dynamics. The PPS is a biennial survey that collects data in odd years about behaviors in even years (e.g., the 2019 wave of the PPS was collected in 2019 about giving in 2018), with a sample size of 7,000 to 9,000 per wave. The PPS limits questions about giving to households that gave at least $25. Therefore, individuals or households that donated between $1 and $24 are marked as nondonors in the PPS data.

measures.name: Share of Americans who reported donating money to a charitable organization in the previous 12 months
measures.notes: Estimates rely on telephone interviews conducted by pollsters with a random sample of more than 1,000 adults living in all 50 states and the District of Columbia. Respondents were asked separately about donating money and volunteering time to charitable organizations. In our November 29, 2022 update, we corrected the 2008 data point, which we had rounded incorrectly. We changed it from 83 percent to 82 percent. We also removed the 2014 data point, which was not included in the source.

measures.name: Percentage change in total number of donors from previous year
measures.notes: Estimates of total donors were calculated by the Fundraising Effectiveness Project using anonymized giving transaction data from a variety of donor software, such as Bloomerang, DonorPerfect, and NeonCRM. Most recent complete annual calculations (2021) are drawn from a random representative sample of 9,652 nonprofit organizations.

measures.name: Donor retention rate
measures.notes: Estimates are provided by the AFP/Fundraising Effectiveness Project.

name: Mutual aid
description: Mutual aid has a long tradition and has been defined in many ways, but at its root, it entails a group, often unincorporated, providing assistance to meet the immediate needs of its neighbors.

measures.name: Number of donations made to mutual aid networks through the ioby crowdfunding platform
measures.notes: Estimates are pulled from raw data provided by ioby, a crowdfunding platform. Because the 2020 estimate only contains data from March through December of that year, the comparison with 2021 is incomplete, but we include it to contextualize change over time. The totals do not include matched contributions made by ioby.

name: Collaborative giving
description: Giving circles are groups that pool their time and money and decide communally where those resources should be donated.

measures.name: Total giving circles in the Global Giving Circle Directory
measures.notes: These estimates were pulled from Philanthropy Together’s Global Giving Circle Directory during the months indicated. The Global Giving Circle Directory is a searchable directory of giving circles created by Philanthropy Together, a global initiative to promote giving circles.

name: Crowdfunding
description: Crowdfunding, which entails large numbers of people each donating small amounts of money, has become more popular in recent years largely because of virtual crowdfunding platforms, such as GoFundMe and DonorsChoose, and apps that have simplified monetary transactions.

measures.name: Total money raised from GoFundMe campaigns since the platform’s founding in 2010
measures.notes: GoFundMe enables individuals to set up crowdfunding campaigns for any purpose. Estimates are sourced from GoFundMe public reports that share estimates of money raised across all campaigns and aggregate all donations made to crowdfunding campaigns across the platform since it was founded in 2010. GoFundMe does not release annual figures.

measures.name: Average crowdfunding gift size

sources.source: Indiana University Lilly Family School of Philanthropy

measures.notes: Estimates were drawn from a 2020 survey of 1,535 US households developed by the Lilly Family School of Philanthropy and fielded using the AmeriSpeak panel by NORC at the University of Chicago. Weights were applied in the analysis to ensure the final sample was representative of US households with respect to age, gender, race/ethnicity, and education.

measures.name: Share of donations made on GoFundMe under $50
measures.notes: GoFundMe enables individuals to set up crowdfunding campaigns for any purpose. Estimates are sourced from GoFundMe public reports for 2019 and 2020, which aggregate all donations made to crowdfunding campaigns across the platform.

measures.name: Total grants and contributions to DonorsChoose
measures.notes: DonorsChoose enables teachers to set up crowdfunding campaigns for classroom projects. Estimates are drawn from DonorsChoose’s public tax records, isolating the contributions and grants component of its annual total revenue.

name: Giving days
description: Giving days, which are organized efforts to mobilize large-scale donations, often use social media to motivate potential donors. The largest giving day, GivingTuesday (the Tuesday after Thanksgiving), was launched in the United States in 2012 and is now hosted in more than 70 countries worldwide.

measures.name: Total dollars donated in the United States on GivingTuesday
measures.notes: Estimates are based on the GivingTuesday Data Collaborative’s statistical model that estimates online and offline giving.

measures.name: Total US online donations made on GivingTuesday
measures.notes: Estimates are based on the GivingTuesday Data Collaborative’s aggregation of transaction data from its network of platform reports each year. In our November 29, 2022 update, we corrected the unit value from “dollar value of donations” to “Number of donations.”
